Industrial Corridor Development Program, Subprogram 1 (RRP IND 54465) 
 
   
Technical Assistance Report
 
 
 
Project Number: 54465-001  
Transaction Technical Assistance Facility (F-TRTA) 
October 2021 
 
 
India: Knowledge Services for Industrial Corridor 
Development Program 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
This document is being disclosed to the public in accordance with ADB’s Access to Information 
Policy.

CURRENCY EQUIVALENTS 
(as of 15 September 2021)

Limited

  TA  –  technical assistance 
 
 
NOTES 
(i)  The fiscal year (FY) of the Government of India ends on 31 March. “FY” before a 
calendar year denotes the year in which the fiscal year ends, e.g., FY2021 ends 
on 31 March 2021. 
(ii)  In this report, "$" refers to United States dollars.

Vice-President  Shixin Chen, Operations 1 
Director General  Kenichi Yokoyama, South Asia Department (SARD)

4 
 
CONTENTS 
 
Page 
 
I.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE FACILITY  1 
A.  Justification  1 
B.  Outputs and Activities  3 
C.  Cost and Financing  4 
D.  Implementation Arrangements  4 
E.  Governance  5 
 
APPENDIXES 
1.  Cost Estimates and Financing Plan  6 
2.  List of Linked Documents  7

I. THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE FACILITY
A. Justification
1. The Asian Development Bank (ADB) will provide a loan of $250 million from its ordinary
capital  resources  for  subprogram  1  of  the  Industrial  Corridor  Development  Program.  The
proposed program consisting of 2 subprograms will strengthen the enabling environment for
effective implementation of the Government of India’s National Industrial Corridor Development
Program, which aims to increase the competitiveness of the manufacturing sector, strengthen
national supply chains and links with regional and global value chains, and create jobs.
2. The Ministry of Commerce and Industry, acting through the Department for Promotion of
Industry and Internal Trade (DPIIT), is the executing agency for the program. The National
Industrial Corridor Development and Implementation Trust (NICDIT) is the implementing agency
along with its knowledge partner, the National Industrial Corridor Development Corporation
Limited (NICDCL). The TA project will strengthen the technical and policy advisory, human
resources, and program management capacity of NICDCL. ADB designed the policy matrix based
on gaps identified in the industrial operating ecosystem. Policy actions are included to ensure
synergy between the industrial corridor development program and the reform agenda of India.1
3. India’s low competitiveness in manufacturing is reflected in the declining contribution of
manufacturing to gross domestic product, India's low share of world manufacturing exports (less
than 2.5%), and a limited number of workers employed by manufacturing firms with 10 or more
workers  (just  17.1  million  workers  in  2015–2016).  Key  factors  impacting  manufacturing
competitiveness include an inadequate institutional environment for coordination between central
and state agencies, which impedes smooth decision-making and implementation of reforms;
cumbersome business processes and high cost of capital;2 challenges in infrastructure, especially
lack of integrated multimodal transport networks leading to high logistics costs;3 bottlenecks in
land availability; rigidities in labor regulation;4 paucity of industry-aligned skilled workforce;5 and
absence of long-term financing for private investment.6
4. The government has identified industrial corridors as an appropriate policy tool to lower
transaction and logistics costs and improve efficiency while targeting large areas of the country
that are earmarked for industrial development. Transaction and logistics costs are high because
of weaknesses in transport infrastructure, especially last-mile connectivity to ports and railways.
Unsynchronized  economic  and  spatial  planning  have failed  to  yield urban–industry  linkage
benefits to firms and workers. Mobilization of long-term finance for industrial sector by deepening
1  The National Industrial Corridor Development Program aims to provide multi modal connectivity with complete “plug 
and play” infrastructure along with building resilient and sustainable future ready cities. https://www.nicdc.in/about-
DMICDC/implementation-framework 
2  While India has made huge strides in improving ease of doing business, it continues to lag in parameters such as 
starting up a business because of the high number of procedures required. Government of India, Ministry of Finance. 
2021. Economic Survey 2020–21. Delhi. 
3  The Statesman. 2020. India needs to lower its logistic cost to 7–8% of GDP: Report. 23 December. Logistics costs 
are estimated to be much higher at 14% of GDP compared to the developed countries and are expected to worsen 
in FY2022 as the pandemic approaches its third year. 
4  An economic survey 2015–2016 noted that firm size in India has remained small because of stringent labor laws 
(lack of an easy exit policy and high administrative burdens). PRS Legislative Research. 2020. Overview of Labor 
Law Reforms. New Delhi. 
5  Labor productivity in manufacturing sector has been low as rigid labor laws force companies to hire casual workers 
rather than regular works. KL Krishna et al. 2018. Trends and Patterns in Labor Quality in India at Sectoral Level. 
Delhi: Centre for Development Economics.  
6  Financial markets are not well developed and depend on public banks and household savings.

2 
 
and diversifying domestic capital markets is key to supporting the development of economic 
corridors in a sustainable manner. Upgrading skills in the local labor force is required to improve 
productivity  in  industrial  corridors—a  prerequisite  for  attracting  private  sector  investment. 
Development of industrial corridors will require a strong apex institutional and regulatory structure 
to target specific locations where multiple constraints can be addressed through coordinated 
planning between national and subnational governments and to promote trade and regional 
integration spanning central, state, and local agencies.  
 
5.  The  transaction  technical  assistance  (TA)  facility  will  provide  capacity-building  and 
advisory services to support reforms under subprogram 2 of the Industrial Corridor Development 
Program. The TA complements the proposed program objective of strengthening the enabling 
environment for national industrial corridor development, and under subprogram 2 will advance 
the mandates of institutions constituted by the government to develop national industrial corridors. 
The TA will provide advisory support to strengthen the capacity of these institutions in developing 
robust planning guidelines and technical, institutional, and regulatory frameworks, particularly in 
the special purpose vehicles (SPVs) in the states. The transaction TA for Knowledge Services for 
Industrial Corridor Development Program is listed in the country operations business plan for India, 
2021–2023.7 
 
6.   NICDIT was set up under DPIIT in 2016. NICDIT will invest based on delegated authority 
from DPIIT in industrial corridors and clusters in partnership with state-level SPVs. NICDCL, 
formerly Delhi–Mumbai Industrial Corridor Development Corporation, was formed in February 
2020 to operationalize industrial corridors and act as a knowledge partner for NICDIT and provide 
advisory services to states. NICDCL is mandated to undertake extensive project development 
activities  across  all  investment  regions  and  industrial  areas,  assist  state  governments  in 
developing master plans for industrial corridors, and provide them with technical and financial 
structuring and corridor planning guidance. However, the new institutions require expanded 
capacity and enhanced knowledge services to be more effective. Given this, the objective of 
subprogram 1 will be to establish the institutional structure and strengthen it with guidelines and 
frameworks on providing knowledge services within industrial corridors, developing skills, and 
creating opportunities for private sector engagement., while subprogram 2 will advance the 
mandates of the new institutions. 
 
7.  The proposed transaction TA will support government initiatives under subprogram 2. The 
TA project will provide advisory services under the three program reform areas (paras. 9–11). The 
TA will support development of NICDCL, NICDIT, and SPVs identified by NICDCL. The TA will 
also support NICDIT and NICDCL to develop new policy guidelines and financing modalities, 
concession  agreements,  and  national  gender-inclusive  policy  frameworks  for  corridor-wide 
operationalization.  The  TA  will  support  the  delivery  of  11  out  of  13  policy  actions  under 
subprogram 2.8 The following consulting services packages will be recruited through the TA 
facility: 
(i)  two individual consultants with intermittent inputs (proposed for October 2021–
September 2023): 
(a)  investment promotion specialist (international, 200 person-days); and 
(b)  finance specialist (international, 200 person-days); and  
 
7  ADB 2020. Country Operational Business Plan: India, 2021–2023. Manila. The TA first appeared in the business 
opportunities section of ADB’s website on 17 June 2021. 
8  Policy actions numbered 2.3, 2.4, 2.5, 2.6, 2.7, 2.8, 2.9, 2.10, 2.12, 2.13, and 2.14, as stated in the policy matrix in 
the approved program concept paper (accessible from Appendix 2, list of linked documents).

3 
 
(ii)  a national consulting firm (proposed for January 2022–September 2023) with a 
team of seven consultants with intermittent inputs: 
(a)  industrial  infrastructure  planning  and  financing  specialist/team  leader 
(national, 140 person-days); 
(b)  project  and  public–private  partnership  (PPP)  specialist  (national,  100 
person-days); 
(c)  urban specialist (national, 140 person-days); 
(d)  land policy and land development specialist (national, 100 person-days); 
(e)  environmental policy specialist (national, 100 person-days); 
(f)  social  development  (Gender  Equality  and  Social  Inclusion)  specialist 
(national, 100 person-days); and 
(g)  skills development specialist (national, 100 person-days). 
 
B.  Outputs and Activities 
 
8.  Output 1 (reform area 1): Institutional structures and mechanisms for industrial 
corridors’ integrated development strengthened. The TA will support NICDIT and NICDCL, 
as the implementing agencies, in facilitating engagement between NICDIT and state-level SPVs 
through partnerships to ensure cluster development and financing plans. 
 
9.  Output 2 (reform area 2): Delivery of integrated and innovative project development 
and  financing  solutions  for  industrial  corridors  improved.  The  TA  will  support  the 
implementing agencies in the following ways: (i) based on new readiness criteria and financing 
modalities, at least five project proposals on development of industrial nodes appraised for 
submission by NICDCL to NICDIT;9 (ii) node/project specific concession agreement for master 
developers in corridor areas approved for at least one SPV board;10 (iii) framework developed on 
industrial housing for employees ensuring safety, security, and convenience, including gender-
related provisions approved by the NICDCL board; (iv) framework developed by NICDCL on 
methodology to enhance industry/urban participation in finalization of master plans for industrial 
corridor development by SPVs; (v) guidelines on human resources process manuals for the node 
SPVs that include gender-inclusive measures in relation to workplace safety, equal opportunity, 
etc. developed and approved by the NICDCL board; and (vi) guidelines that ensure compliance 
with  requisite  environmental  and  social  safeguards  and  climate-resilient  infrastructure 
development in industrial corridor areas developed and approved by the NICDCL Board. 
 
10.  Output 3 (reform area 3): Integrated investment in industrial corridors facilitated 
and promoted. The TA will support the NICDCL and DPIIT in the following ways: (i) an action 
framework containing processes and methodologies of land policy enablers at the nodes in the 
corridors will be prepared by NICDCL to provide guidance and series of interventions for adoption 
by SPVs during the various stages of land allotment process.;11 (ii) a concession agreement 
prepared for operationalization of utility companies approved by at least one SPV’s Board; and 
(iii) industrial park rating system criteria expanded by DPIIT by including sex disaggregated data 
on labor force of industrial parks for the period FY2023–FY2024. 
 
9  An industrial node is a geographic area within an industrial area or an investment region within an industrial corridor. 
10  A master developer is a private sector developer who will lease land from the government and focus on attracting 
strategic investments and jobs to an industrial region by strategically marketing and bringing in relevant and/or large 
anchor tenants and investors from focus industries/clusters. 
11 Industrial Land Allotment Enablers provide guidance and series of interventions for adoption by SPVs during the 
various stages of land allotment process. It provides action plan for the SPVs to implement the initiatives under the 
three broad categories of interventions—Policy, Administrative and Technical.

4 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
11.  The TA facility is estimated to cost $1,100,000, of which $1,000,000 will be financed on a 
grant  basis  by  ADB’s  Technical  Assistance  Special  Fund  (TASF–other  sources).  The  key 
expenditure items are listed in Appendix 1. 
 
12.  The government will provide counterpart support in the form of counterpart staff, office 
space, workshop facilities, office supplies, administrative help, logistics support, and other in-kind 
contributions. The government was informed that approval of the TA does not commit ADB to 
finance any ensuing project. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
13.  India, through the Ministry of Finance, will be the borrower for the program. Ministry of 
Commerce and Industry, through DPIIT, will be the executing agency of the TA facility. NICDIT, 
with NICDCL as its knowledge partner, will be the implementing agency for the TA facility. Funds 
will be channeled to SPVs from NICDIT. ADB, through the South Asia Public Management, 
Financial Sector, and Trade Division, will be responsible for TA facility administration and will work 
closely with the executing and implementing agencies to support implementation of the planned 
activities. ADB will be responsible for the recruitment, management, and administration of all 
consultants financed by the TA facility. ADB will inform DPIIT, NICDIT, and NICDCL of selected 
consultants prior to their mobilization. The TA facility for subprogram 2 will be implemented over 
2 years, from October 2021 to September 2023. Disbursement under the TA facility will be in 
accordance with ADB’s Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2020, as amended from 
time to time). 
 
14.  The implementation arrangements are summarized in the table. 
 
Implementation Arrangements 
Aspects  Arrangements 
Indicative implementation  October 2021–September 2023 
period

Commerce and Industry 
{Implementing agencies}  National Industrial Corridor Development and Implementation Trust 
(with its knowledge partner National Industrial Corridor Development 
Corporation Limited). For practical purposes, the TA will be managed 
by ADB in close coordination with the implementing agency and its 
knowledge partner. 
Consultants  To be selected and engaged by ADB 
  One consulting firm:  National  $423,000 
QCBS (90:10) 
  Two individual  International; 400 person- $328,000 
consultants: ICS   days (October 2021–
September 2023)

Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2020, as amended from time to 
time). 
ADB = Asian Development Bank, ICS = individual consultant selection, QCBS = quality- and cost-based selection, 
TA = technical assistance. 
Source: Asian Development Bank.

5 
 
15.  Consulting services. The TA facility will support subprogram 2 delivery through (i) 400 
person-days (proposed from October 2021 to September 2023) provided by two international 
individual  consultants  on  knowledge  sharing,  investment  promotion,  and  private  sector 
engagement; review of existing and proposed concession agreements; and overall policy advisory 
services; and (ii) 780 person-days (proposed from January 2022 to September 2023) provided by 
a national consulting firm on knowledge and policy advisory services to facilitate delivery of the 
mandates of institutions such as DPIIT, NICDIT, NICDICL, and SPVs, so that reforms are 
undertaken at the national level across central line ministries and agencies and at the state level 
within the policy-based loan period of 2020−2024. The TA will help NICDCL develop new policy 
guidelines and financing modalities, concession agreements, and national gender-inclusive policy 
frameworks for corridor-wide operationalization. As the risk categorization of the program is 
complex, the national consulting firm under the transaction TA will be recruited using quality- and 
cost-based selection (QCBS ratio of 90:10) and full technical proposal. As part of the TA 
assignment, consultants may need to visit few major industrial corridor nodes/cities in the key 
states of Andhra Pradesh, Gujarat, Karnataka, Madhya Pradesh, Maharashtra, Odisha, and Tamil 
Nadu. ADB will engage the consultants following the ADB Procurement Policy (2017, as amended 
from time to time) and its associated project administration instructions and/or staff instructions.12 
 
E.  Governance  
 
16.  DPIIT follows national laws on public financial management, while employees abide by 
the conditions of ethics in the national government's published gazettes. The regular statutory 
external audit is done by the Office of the Comptroller and Auditor General of India (Supreme 
Audit Institution of India). Budgeting is linked to fiscal targets, under the Fiscal Responsibility and 
Budget Management Act, 2010, which aims to ensure prudence in fiscal management and fiscal 
stability. ADB financing will be provided as budget support. There is no transfer of resources to 
the implementing agencies specifically for policy actions, other than through the usual annual 
budgetary approval procedures. ADB’s Anticorruption Policy (1998, as amended to date) was 
explained to and discussed with the central government's Ministry of Finance. ADB’s website link 
for  reporting  fraud  and  corruption  was  shared  with  the  Ministry  of  Finance  and 
implementing agencies. 
 
12 Terms of Reference for Consultants (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2).

6  Appendix 1

The value of the government contribution is estimated to account for $10,000 or 9% of the total TA cost.
